excerpt: Renaissance palace with tranquil courtyards & formal garden, plus art & antiques collection.
detail_description: Palacio de Viana is a Renaissance palace in Cordoba, known for its tranquil courtyards and formal gardens. It houses an impressive collection of art, jewelry, and antiques. The palace, also called Museo de los Patios, features 12 distinct patios with unique decorations.
name: Palacio de Viana
address: Pl. de Don Gome, 2, Centro, 14001 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Ornate, Moorish-style place of worship, with a hall of arched pillars & a basilica with frescos.
detail_description: The Mosque-Cathedral Monumental Site of Córdoba is a stunning blend of Moorish, Christian, and Arab architectural styles. This historic building showcases the city's rich cultural and religious heritage. It was originally an Islamic mosque dating back to 780 AD before being converted into a Catholic cathedral in the 1230s. The site attracts over 1.5 million visitors annually who are captivated by its ornate hall of arched pillars and basilica adorned with frescos.
name: Mosque-Cathedral Monumental Site of Córdoba
address: C. Cardenal Herrero, º 1, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Long, restored bridge with many arcades originally constructed in the early 1st century BCE.
detail_description: The Roman Bridge of Córdoba, also known as Puente Romano, is a historic structure dating back to the 1st century BC. Spanning the Guadalquivir River with its 17 stone arches, this bridge offers stunning views of Cordoba and its surrounding countryside. Originally built during Roman rule, it has undergone multiple renovations over the centuries. Today, it remains a beloved local landmark and an integral part of city life in Córdoba.
name: Roman Bridge of Córdoba
address: Av. del Alcázar, s/n, Sur, 14009 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Narrow & sinuous white-washed alley, where balconies are filled with flowers.
detail_description: Calleja de las Flores is a narrow and winding white-washed alley in Cordoba, known for its balconies adorned with vibrant flowers. This charming street showcases the traditional patios of Cordoba's architecture, reflecting the Moorish influence with sturdy white walls to provide sanctuary from the intense summer sun. During the annual Patio Festival in May, private patios are opened to the public and adorned with beautiful flowers for a municipal competition.
name: Calleja de las Flores
address: 1, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Plaza de la Corredera is a vibrant and historic square in Cordoba that captures the essence of local life. This expansive plaza, reminiscent of Italy's famous squares, is a hub for socializing, dining, and enjoying the lively atmosphere filled with restaurants and bars. Here, you can sip drinks on terraces where bulls once roamed while soaking in the rich history surrounding you.
name: Pl. de la Corredera
address: Centro, 14002 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Jardines del Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos, also known as the Castle of the Christian Monarchs, was constructed in 1328 and has been a residence for Spanish rulers. The fortress offers stunning views from its four towers and features lavish mosaic-decorated halls that showcase the opulent lifestyle of royalty. However, the highlight is undoubtedly the exquisite gardens, which provide countless opportunities for picturesque photos.
name: Jardines del Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos
address: C. Caballerizas Reales, s/n, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Mudéjar-style 1300s palace with terraced gardens, Roman mosaics & Gothic towers for panoramic views.
detail_description: The Alcazar of the Christian Monarchs, also known as Alcazar de los Reyes Cristianos, is a medieval palace-fortress in Cordoba, Spain. Built in the 1300s on the site of an old Muslim Caliphate palace, it features Mudéjar-style architecture, terraced gardens, Roman mosaics, and Gothic towers offering panoramic views.
name: Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos
address: C. Caballerizas Reales, s/n, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Well-preserved medieval Jewish place of worship with courtyard, stuccoed hall & women's balcony.
detail_description: Córdoba Synagogue is a well-preserved medieval Jewish place of worship located in the heart of the city's Jewish Quarter. It is one of the prime examples of Cordoba's rich history, reflecting the coexistence of Christian, Islamic, and Jewish cultures. The synagogue, built in the 14th century, showcases exquisite Mudejar architecture and features a courtyard, stuccoed hall, and women's balcony.
name: Córdoba Synagogue
address: C. Judíos, 20, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Tower offering panoramic views, plus a town museum featuring waxworks & a model of the Alhambra.
detail_description: Located in Cordoba's historic center, Torre De Calahorra is the oldest defense building in the city, believed to have been constructed during Islamic times. Over the years, it has served various purposes including as a prison and a school for girls. Today, it houses the museum of Al-Andalus which showcases the Christian, Muslim and Jewish cultures that influenced Cordoba's past.
name: Torre de la Calahorra
address: Puente Romano, s/n, Sur, 14009 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Traditional, Arabian-style bath complex offering a variety of massage & beauty treatments.
detail_description: Hammam Al Andalus is a traditional Arabian-style bath complex located in the heart of the Barrio de Santa Cruz, Seville's UNESCO-protected old quarter. Housed in a stunning 16th-century palace, it offers a variety of massage and beauty treatments. The baths provide an authentic Arab hammam experience with salt water baths, steam rooms, and large bathing areas. After the rejuvenating experience, visitors can relax in a plant-filled patio while enjoying tea and Moroccan-style sweets.
name: Hammam Al Andalus
address: C. Corregidor Luis de la Cerda, 51, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Gate near a Roman bridge with history exhibits & a viewpoint, once part of defensive city walls.
detail_description: Puerta del Puente is a historic gate located near a Roman bridge in Cordoba, Spain. Despite its Roman-style architecture, it was actually built in the 16th century to commemorate a royal visit. Over the centuries, it has been rebuilt and expanded, serving as a grand entrance to the city. The gate features history exhibits and offers a viewpoint of the surrounding area. It holds significance as it replaced original Roman gates into the city and has undergone various modifications over time.
name: Puerta del Puente
address: Pl. del Triunfo, s/n, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Series of courtyards bedecked with plants & flowers, celebrated in May with citywide festivities.
detail_description: In Cordoba, the Patios Cordobeses are a series of stunning courtyards adorned with vibrant plants and flowers. These patios are celebrated in May with a citywide festival, where locals compete for the prestigious award of the best patio. For a small fee, visitors can gain admission to all the patios and receive a map to guide them through these beautiful spaces.
name: Patios Cordobeses
address: C. San Basilio, 44, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Small site with Roman temple ruins, including reconstructed pillars, surrounded by modern buildings.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Cordoba, the Templo Romano stands as a captivating testament to the city’s rich Roman heritage. Dating back to the 1st century AD and initiated during Emperor Claudius's reign, these impressive ruins were only discovered in the 1950s. Today, visitors can marvel at six magnificent Corinthian columns that rise majestically against a backdrop of modern architecture.
name: Templo Romano
address: C. Capitulares, 1, Centro, 14002 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Medina Azahara 1ª is a fascinating and mysterious city built by Abd-al Rahman III, located at the foot of the Sierra Morena, just eight kilometers from Cordoba. Legend has it that after proclaiming himself caliph in 929 AD, Abd al Rahman III decided to honor his favorite, Azahara, by building this palatine city. The site offers guided tours and night visits with magnificent lighting that showcase its splendor.
name: Medina Azahara 1ª
address: Poniente Sur, 14005 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Córdoba is a city in the southern Spanish region of Andalusia, and the capital of the province of Córdoba. It was an important Roman city and a major Islamic center in the Middle Ages. It’s best known for La Mezquita, an immense mosque dating from 784 A.D., featuring a columned prayer hall and older Byzantine mosaics. After it became a Catholic church in 1236, a Renaissance-style nave was added in the 17th century.
detail_description: Córdoba, located in the southern Spanish region of Andalusia, is a city steeped in history and cultural significance. Once an important Roman city and later a major Islamic center, it boasts architectural marvels such as La Mezquita, a stunning mosque dating back to 784 A.D. that features a columned prayer hall and Byzantine mosaics.
name: Córdoba
address: Spain

excerpt: Town square with notable buildings including a famed mosque-cathedral plus shops, cafes & fountains.
name: Pl. de las Tendillas
address: Centro, Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: In Cordoba, the Royal Stables, also known as Caballerizas Reales de Cordoba, offer an exciting Equestrian Show in the San Basilio neighborhood. Established in 1570 by King Philip II of Spain to breed purebred Andalusian horses, these stables played a significant role in shaping the Spanish empire.
name: Royal Stables
address: C. Caballerizas Reales, 1, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: The grand Mosque-Cathedral with its Moorish colonnades is at the heart of La Catedral district. Streets in its former Jewish Quarter are dotted with ornately tiled courtyards decked in flowers. The imposing Puerta del Puente arch and restored Roman Bridge over the Guadalquivir River contrast with the delicate Mudéjar style of the synagogue and Hammam Al Andalus baths. Open-air tapas bars stay busy late at night.
detail_description: La Judería, also known as the old Jewish quarter, is a charming and historic neighborhood in Cordoba. It features narrow lanes, whitewashed houses, and flower-filled patios that create a distinctive atmosphere. The area has a rich history dating back to Roman times when Jews first settled there. Visitors can explore important Jewish monuments such as the 15th-century Mudejar-style Sinagoga de Cordoba and the Casa de Sefarad museum.
name: La Judería
address: Centro, Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Marketlike hub of gastrobars & deli stands, with vendors specializing in Andalusian tapas & sherry.
detail_description: Mercado Victoria is a bustling hub of gourmet food stalls and tapas bars in Cordoba. It's a popular spot for both locals and tourists to pick up high-end cheeses, cured meats, wines, and olive oils as souvenirs. The market offers a lively atmosphere where Cordobese foodies gather to shop for daily essentials and exchange gossip. After shopping, visitors can relax at the posh tapas outlets with cold beer and tasty snacks.
name: Mercado Victoria
address: P.º de la Victoria, s/nº, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: The Mezquita de los Andaluces is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in the oldest neighborhoods of Cordoba, Spain. The area is filled with historic monuments, cobblestoned plazas, and narrow Moorish lanes lined with artisan shops. Visitors can explore the winding lanes of the Jewish Quarter and admire the famous Calleja de las Flores for picturesque views of the Mezquita belltower. It's within walking distance from the Mosque-Cathedral of Cordoba.
name: Mezquita de los Andaluces
address: Calleja de la Hoguera, 3, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Puente Romano is a luxurious beachfront resort located in Marbella, Spain. The resort offers a range of upscale amenities including multiple swimming pools, tennis courts, and a world-class spa. Guests can choose from a variety of fine dining options on-site, as well as enjoy easy access to the nearby beach. The rooms and suites are elegantly designed with modern comforts and some offer stunning views of the Mediterranean Sea.
name: Puente Romano
address: Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Archeology artifacts spanning all eras from prehistory to the Middle Ages, plus Moorish art.
detail_description: Nestled in the stunning Renaissance architecture of the former Paez de Castillejo palace, the Córdoba Archaeological Museum is a treasure trove for history enthusiasts. This remarkable museum showcases an extensive collection of artifacts that span from prehistory to the Middle Ages, including significant pieces from Iberian, Roman, and Visigoth cultures.
name: Córdoba Archaeological Museum
address: Pl. de Jerónimo Páez, 7, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Landmark mosque-cathedral courtyard with a fountain & planted with cypresses & orange trees.
detail_description: Patio de los Naranjos, located within the Mosque-Cathedral, is a historic courtyard adorned with cypress and orange trees. This tranquil oasis has been a feature for centuries, offering shade and fragrance during Cordoba's hot summers. The courtyard also hosts evening entrances with light shows and theatrical performances that unveil the essence of Cordoba. Surrounding the Patio de los Naranjos are cloisters made of various marbles, leading to a sanctuary supported by numerous pillars and arches.
name: Patio de los Naranjos
address: C. Cardenal Herrero, 1, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Public square lined with historic buildings, a Renaissance fountain & monument of archangel Raphael.
detail_description: Pl. del Potro is a charming public square adorned with historic buildings and a Renaissance fountain. The centerpiece of the square is a monument dedicated to the archangel Raphael, adding a touch of cultural and artistic significance to the area.
name: Pl. del Potro
address: Centro, Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Popular walking tour of historic hidden courtyards festooned with elaborate potted floral displays.
detail_description: Patios de San Basilio is a must-visit destination in Cordoba, offering a delightful experience of exploring historic hidden courtyards adorned with elaborate potted floral displays. Situated in the Alcazar Viejo area, this attraction comprises three beautiful courtyards that captivate visitors with their charm. The ticket for entry includes a guided visit, access to the Ethnographic Museum, and an opportunity for wine tasting.
name: Patios de San Basilio
address: C. Martín de Roa, 2, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Royal stables, commissioned in the 16th century, featuring a track & equestrian events.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Córdoba, Caballerizas Reales is a stunning example of 16th-century architecture that once served as royal stables. This historic site not only showcases impressive equestrian events but also offers visitors a glimpse into the rich cultural heritage of the city. While exploring, don't miss other nearby attractions like the Jewish quarter and Calahorra tower. For an immersive experience, consider joining a guided tour or following themed routes that highlight Córdoba's Roman past and medieval churches.
name: Caballerizas Reales
address: C. Caballerizas Reales, 1, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Nestled within the historic walls of the former Hospital de la Caridad, the Museo Julio Romero de Torres is a treasure trove for art enthusiasts and history buffs alike. This museum proudly showcases an extensive collection dedicated to the illustrious Cordoban painter, Julio Romero de Torres, celebrated for his symbolist style and captivating portraits. Visitors can embark on a visual journey through his artistic evolution, from early works to iconic pieces like 'La Chiquita Piconera' and 'Cante Hondo.'
name: Museo Julio Romero de Torres
address: Pl. del Potro, 1-4, Centro, 14002 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Small museum tracing local Jewish heritage with a variety of cultural & historical exhibits.
detail_description: Casa de Sefarad, also known as the House of Sepharad, is a small museum located in the heart of the Jewish Quarter of Cordoba. It serves as a cultural center dedicated to preserving and showcasing the heritage of Sephardic Jews in the Mediterranean. The museum features permanent exhibitions and cultural activities that aim to revive interest in this often overlooked heritage.
name: Casa de Sefarad
address: C. Judíos, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Museum dedicated to bullfighting traditions & history, including photos, paintings & costumes.
detail_description: The Bullfighting Museum of Cordoba is a dedicated space showcasing the traditions and history of bullfighting. It features an array of exhibits including photos, paintings, and traditional costumes. Situated in the Plaza of Las Bulas, it holds memories of renowned bullfighters from Cordoba. The museum provides insight into the local bullfighting history, including events at the Plaza de Toros Los Califas Auditorio just outside town.
name: Bullfighting Museum of Cordoba
address: Pl. Maimónides, 3, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Museum with informational exhibits in an elaborate, medieval Moorish bath complex.
detail_description: Baños del Alcázar Califal is a museum housed in the remains of an elaborate medieval Moorish bath complex. Unearthed in 1903 and later excavated between 1961 and 1964, these baths, known as hammam, were part of the Omeyan Castle and one of the largest of their kind in Cordoba. Left in ruins for centuries, they have been partially reconstructed and are now open to visitors as a museum.
name: Baños del Alcázar Califal
address: Pl. Campo Santo de los Mártires, s/n, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Tortillas, tapas & beers are dished up in this popular, compact destination with a homey vibe.
detail_description: Bar Santos is a cozy and popular spot known for its delicious tapas, tortillas, and beers. Despite its small size and lack of seating, the bar exudes a charmingly authentic Spanish vibe with its decor featuring photos of matadors and flamenco dancers. The prices are reasonable, adding to the appeal of this quintessentially Spanish establishment. The menu offers excellent quality tapas such as albondigas en salsa de almendras and bocadillos at great value.
name: Bar Santos
address: C. Magistral González Francés, 3, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Cordoba, a city with a rich history and the only one in the modern world to host four UNESCO World Heritage sites, including the famous Mezquita Mosque and Cathedral. One of its main attractions is the Ruta de Patios Córdoba, especially beautiful in May when flowers are blooming. The route includes six patios to visit, some of which are free or accept donations. Despite being often overlooked by tourists, these patios are a must-see.
name: Ruta de Patios Córdoba
address: C. San Basilio, 14, LOCAL, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Patios is a charming restaurant located in the heart of the city, known for its cozy and inviting atmosphere. The menu features a variety of delicious dishes, including fresh seafood, juicy steaks, and flavorful pasta. The outdoor patio area is perfect for enjoying al fresco dining on warm evenings. With its friendly staff and relaxed ambiance, Patios is a great spot for casual get-togethers or romantic dinners.
name: Patios
address: C. Virrey Caballero Góngora, 12, Poniente Sur, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

name: Centro de Exposiciones, Ferias y Convenciones de Córdoba (CEFC)
address: Junto al Parque Joyero, Av. de la Fábrica, s/n, 14005 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Museum housed in a historic space featuring centuries of paintings & sculptures by Spanish artists.
detail_description: The Museum of Fine Arts of Cordoba, established in 1862, is housed in a historic space and showcases centuries of paintings and sculptures by Spanish artists. Its collections originated from goods confiscated from different convents due to the disentailment of Mendizabal.
name: Museum of Fine Arts of Cordoba
address: Pl. del Potro, 1, Centro, 14002 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Manicured botanical garden with greenhouses, a collection of endangered species & an arboretum.
detail_description: The Real Jardín Botánico de Córdoba is a manicured green space that houses endangered species, boasts beautiful greenhouses, and features an arboretum. It is highly recommended for families visiting Cordoba, especially those with children who will enjoy exploring its gardens. Located near the city center, this botanical garden offers a peaceful escape into nature with its abundant vegetation, open squares, and decorative fountains.
name: Real Jardín Botánico de Córdoba
address: Av. Linneo, s/n, Poniente Sur, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: San Lorenzo is a must-visit for church enthusiasts, along with San Miguel. These churches were constructed under the directive of King Ferdinand III of Castile to repopulate the city with Christians. Interestingly, many of these churches were refurbished from former mosques, adding to their historical significance.
name: San Lorenzo
address: Centro, Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Garum 2.1 Bistró is a trendy gastrobar located at the end of Calle San Fernando, in Cordoba's old town. It offers a fusion of traditional Spanish dishes like tortilla and salmorejo with modern and innovative twists, earning it a reputation for serving some of the best versions of these classics in the city.
name: Garum 2.1 Bistró
address: C. de San Fernando, 122, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: The medieval Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos castle and its terraced gardens dominate San Basilio, also known as Alcázar Viejo. Visitors wander in the area’s tiled, flower-filled courtyards, and the Royal Stables hosts equestrian shows. The square Torre de Belén gate forms part of the original city walls. Traditional tapas bars and tavernas are tucked away in whitewashed houses with shutters.
detail_description: San Basilio, also known as Alcázar Viejo, is a picturesque neighborhood in Andalusia with its medieval Alcázar de los Reyes Cristianos castle and terraced gardens. The area boasts tiled courtyards filled with flowers and hosts equestrian shows at the Royal Stables. Visitors can explore the original city walls featuring the square Torre de Belén gate.
name: San Basilio
address: Centro, Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: The Interpretation Center of the Fiesta de los Patios is a significant part of Cordoba's cultural heritage, as it holds four UNESCO World Heritage inscriptions. The festival takes place in May when the city is at its most beautiful, with participants opening their courtyards to visitors, showcasing stunning domestic gardens filled with blooming flowers. This tradition dates back to Roman times when homes were built with central patios to combat the hot, dry climate.
name: Interpretation Center of the Fiesta de los Patios
address: C. Trueque, 4, Centro, 14002 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Traditional flamenco costumes, music & dancing showcased in a 17th century palace.
detail_description: When visiting Córdoba, one cannot miss the enchanting experience of Tablao Flamenco El Cardenal, nestled within a stunning 17th-century palace. This venue beautifully showcases traditional flamenco music and dance, immersing guests in the rich cultural heritage of Andalusia. After enjoying an exhilarating performance, take time to explore the local culinary scene by indulging in tapas at nearby historic quarters or charming neighborhoods like San Lorenzo and Santa Marina.
name: Tablao Flamenco El Cardenal
address: C. Buen Pastor, 2, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Charming Santa Marina is dominated by the medieval Santa Marina church, featuring Mudéjar plasterwork in its Orozco Chapel. A graceful monument to bullfighter Manolete is nearby on cobbled Plaza del Conde de Priego. Steps away are flower-filled courtyards and formal gardens at the elegant Renaissance Palacio de Viana. Tiled tavernas serving cod and chorizo tapas are scattered in the maze of streets.
detail_description: Santa Marina is a charming area dominated by the medieval Santa Marina church, known for its Mudéjar plasterwork in the Orozco Chapel. Nearby, visitors can find a graceful monument to bullfighter Manolete on the cobbled Plaza del Conde de Priego. The elegant Renaissance Palacio de Viana features flower-filled courtyards and formal gardens just steps away. Tiled tavernas serving traditional Spanish tapas like cod and chorizo are scattered throughout the maze of streets.
name: Santa Marina
address: Centro, 14001 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Calleja del Salmorejo Cordobés is a must-visit alley in Cordoba, known for its connection to the traditional Andalusian dish, Salmorejo Cordobes. This chilled delicacy is made from tomatoes, bread, garlic, olive oil, and sherry vinegar. While it bears some resemblance to gazpacho, it offers a unique culinary experience. The alley features a tile with the authentic recipe for this local specialty.
name: Calleja del salmorejo cordobés
address: Calleja Arcos, 2, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Night Room TV organizes amazing events with great music, unique locations, and a fantastic atmosphere. Their Utopia festival was a wonderful experience due to the beautiful environment and excellent organization. The hallmark of Night Room TV is the carefully chosen settings for their eye-catching and fun events. They create magnificent shows in incomparable city settings, making each event a memorable experience.
name: Night Room TV
address: C. Murcia, 9, Levante, 14010 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: The Centro de Flamenco Fosforito is a top-notch flamenco museum located in Andalucia, offering a comprehensive look into the history of flamenco. The center features exhibits, films, and information panels in both English and Spanish, providing insights into the evolution of flamenco and its prominent figures. Visitors can engage with touch-screen videos showcasing essential flamenco techniques such as song, guitar playing, dance, and percussion.
name: Centro de Flamenco Fosforito
address: Pl. del Potro, 10, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Plaza de Judá Levi is a bustling square located in the heart of Cordoba's Jewish Quarter. It's a perfect spot to take a break and enjoy some local cuisine while immersing yourself in the lively atmosphere of this historic area. After lunch, you can explore the nearby Palacio de Viana, renowned for its magnificent mansion and stunning collection of 12 outdoor patio gardens.
name: Pl. de Judá Levi
address: Centro, Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Casa Andalusí, a 12th-century building located in the heart of Cordoba's Jewish quarter, offers visitors a glimpse into the lifestyle of medieval Al-Andalus. The house reflects the typical dwelling model of that era and showcases a blend of Arab and Andalusian influences in its architecture and decor. Divided into several rooms, Casa Andalusí provides a richly symbolic space for understanding Moorish lifestyle.
name: Casa Andalusí
address: C. Judíos, 12, Centro, 14004 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Small square featuring a landmark circa-1794 crucifix sculpture with 8 lanterns.
detail_description: Cristo de los Faroles is a significant landmark in Cordoba, dating back to 1794. This statue of Christ on the cross is surrounded by eight vintage street lamps, creating a beautiful and atmospheric sight, especially at night. Located in Capuchin Square, it holds deep religious significance for locals and serves as a place for prayer outside of regular church hours. The symbolism of holiness and light is impressive, making it a must-see destination in the historical center of Cordoba.
name: Cristo de los Faroles
address: Pl. de Capuchinos, s/n, Centro, 14001 Córdoba, Spain

excerpt: Fortresslike Catholic church dating from the 1300s, with Gothic & Mudejar architectural features.
detail_description: The Royal Church of Santa Marina de Aguas Santas is a fortress-like Catholic church with a rich history dating back to the 13th century. It features a blend of Gothic and Mudejar architectural styles, reflecting its historical significance. Commissioned by King Ferdinand III after capturing Cordoba from Moorish occupants in 1236, the church has withstood earthquakes and fire over the centuries, undergoing extensive renovations as a result.
name: Royal Church of Santa Marina de Aguas Santas
address: Pl. de Sta. Marina, 6, Centro, 14001 Córdoba, Spain

detail_description: Molino de la Albolafia is an ancient water mill located near the Roman Bridge and the Mezquita/Cathedral. The mill, built to supply water to the Royal Palace - The Alcazar opposite, stands as a reminder of medieval design in a beautiful setting. Despite its current state, it remains quite impressive and offers a glimpse into the city's historical heritage.
name: Molino de Albolafia
address: Av. del Alcázar, 512, Centro, 14003 Córdoba, Spain
